Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: It’s possible that the getAbsolutePosition method is returning a Rotation2D rather than a double.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked:
CuteRedpandas:

Rotation2D

That does seem to be one of the errors in the line but I am not sure what data will make that registry happy.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked:
we do have a getRawAbsolute position that should return a double in our encoder subsystem but it says  it cannot be resolved or is not a field in the line of code with the error.

private double getRawAbsolutePosition() { return encoder.getAverageVoltage() / RobotController.getVoltage5V(); }

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Ok I realize now that you’re using a custom class for the thrifty encoder. Could you also send the code in that class?

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: You’re passing a “ CAN ID” as the analog input number.  There are only 8 analog inputs (numbered 0-7) on the RIO, so presumably one of those constants is equal to 8.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked: Ahh since they are analog inputs they should not be the canID but the id of the analog slot. 0-3 that the encoders are pugged into.  Thanks will pass that along to the student to see if they can figure out how that should be defined instead to get the value 0-3 that matches the canid of the motor they are attached to.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked: we just created new variables for that and it now works thanks next step tuning wish us luck

Adding onto this, we are now experiencing an issue with our code build. When attempting to build the code we get this message:

None of us are really sure what’s going on here any help would be appreciated

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
Did you follow step 3 of the setup instructions? Git must be installed to build the AdvantageKit template projects.

AdvantageKit includes two swerve project templates with built-in support for advanced features:
